Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Stable Carbenes as Surface Anchoring Groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Jeremiah A. Johnson at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is supported by an award from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program to chemically modify the surfaces of several-nanometer-sized particles (nanoparticles) in order to make them more useful for different functions. A broad range of modern technologies, e.g., electronics, diagnostic systems, sensors, drug delivery agents, etc., rely on controlled, robust coating of the nanoparticle surface with layers of molecules that will react in particular ways with other molecules; this is called surface functionalization. It is quite surprising that chemical methods for surface functionalization are relatively few in number, involving only a handful of reactions for most applications, and each of these methods has limitations. As a result, new approaches to produce and use single layers of functional monolayers could drastically impact a wide range of technologies. The research in this project focuses on the development of particular carbene families (reactive carbon compounds) as a new way of making single-layer surface modifications of nanoparticles. This carbene chemistry offers a potentially ideal combination of strong surface bonding and synthetic versatility with the potential to be the ideal platform for different modern nanoparticle technologies. The research encompasses fundamental studies of NHC-layer formation, as well as applications of this technology to electronics and drug delivery. This CAREER proposal research is being integrated with an outreach program focused on the development of a Nanoscience Day and science fair at an elementary and high school.

This proposal seeks to develop addressable N-heterocyclic carbenes (ANHCs) as versatile ligands for the fabrication of novel metal-organic interfaces. This goal is being pursued through three research thrusts: (1) a library of ANHCs with varied steric bulk and reactivity is being synthesized and studied in the context of film formation on various substrates; (2) the scope of surface-initiated polymerization from ANHC surfaces is being expanded to include a variety of semiconducting polymers and other polymeric nanostructures; (3) the electronic properties of bis-NHCs and metal-organic ANHC wires is being studied using the scanning tunneling microscopy break junction (STMBJ) technique. The synthetic diversity of the proposed ANHCs, the ability to form ANHC monolayers on a wide array of substrates and subsequently functionalize those monolayers, and the potential to form conductive ANHC-metal interfaces makes the proposed research a platform technology for a variety of surface modification applications. Furthermore, the results of this research are being integrated with a comprehensive education plan that includes course development within MIT and extramural graduate, undergraduate, high school, and elementary education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surface coatings are ubiquitous in modern life, yet next-generation technologies such as quantum computing, nanomedicine, biosensing, catalysis, single-molecule electronics, and nanofabrication require the development of increasingly thinner and thinner surface coatings. As we push toward the thinnest possible coatings, or single "monolayers" of molecules, the stability and functionality of such systems become key factors that determine their overall utility and performance in a given application. Traditionally, ligands such as thiols have been used to form molecular monolayers on metal (e.g., gold) surfaces. Though they represent an extremely important technology, the instability of thiol-metal interfaces has limited the applications of such coatings, and has driven the search for novel, more robust monolayers.

This project has focused on the development of N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) as a new class of molecules for forming robust monolayers on surfaces. The results have established NHCs as a broadly useful and powerful class of ligands for surface chemistry, with particularly notable enhancements in stability compared to previously used ligand technologies. These studies described the first use of NHCs to form gold nanoparticles and nanorods with high stability in biological media, setting the stage for the use of NHCs in biomedicine and sensing. It also established NHCs and related carbenes as being promising candidates for silicon surface modification, which may impact the computing industry. Lastly, through support of curiosity driven academic research, it led to publication of the first comprehensive review article summarize the use of carbenes in surface chemistry, which has stimulated the field and led to widespread use of NHCs by research groups around the world.

Along with these scientific impacts, this project supported a diverse team of reseachers at the high school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral levels, leading to invaluable training opportunities that have immeasurably impacted the careers of several young scientists. For example, Dr. Alekandr Zhukhovitskiy, whose PhD Thesis was dedicated to this research, received the Nobel Laureate Signature Award for Graduate Education, perhaps the highest honor for a PhD thesis in the United States. Moreover, he received the Henkel Award for Outstanding Graduate Polymer Research. He is now an Assistant Professor of Chemistry at UNC Chapel Hill. Other members of this project, including Dr. Eileen Burke, Dr. Michelle MacLeod, and Dr. Nolan Gallagher, moved on to top industry careers both at large companies (e.g., 3M) and startups. 

Lastly, this project supported several outreach activities, including mentoring of visiting students through the MIT Summer Research Program for underrepresented minority students. In addition, members of the Johnson groupmade two visits to the Boston Cradles to Crayons facility where they helped to prepare school supplied for teachers and students in neighborhoods of need throughout the Boston area.
